This is a big pain point for Skylines 2 right now. You're not going to manage traffic or anything like that in Tropico, though there are vehicles driving and goods moving around in trucks. I'm playing through the story missions and so far they are interesting enough to feel rewarding. Tropico 6 embraces everything that made the series iconic: witty political satire, charismatic dictatorship, and the satisfying chaos of running a Caribbean island nation. As El Presidente, you juggle city-building, economics, diplomacy, and the occasional… creative interpretation of democracy.

The game shines through its sense of humor and personality. The radio banter, absurd political demands, and over-the-top edicts keep the experience lively. Visually, the archipelago system is a major upgrade - building across multiple islands adds strategy and encourages complex layouts instead of just one giant megacity.

Mechanically, it offers a solid mix of depth and accessibility. Managing factions, trade routes, and citizen happiness feels engaging without overwhelming newcomers. Long-time fans will appreciate quality-of-life improvements, smoother interfaces, and more flexible transportation systems.

It’s not without flaws. The campaign writing can feel repetitive, and the pacing occasionally slows down in the late game when waiting for money or resources to roll in. Some buildings still behave unpredictably, and pathfinding occasionally acts like citizens are on vacation more than at work. But none of these issues break the experience.

Overall, Tropico 6 is one of the strongest entries in the franchise - colorful, clever, and packed with charm. Whether you enjoy micromanaging a banana republic or unleashing your inner benevolent tyrant, it’s a fun, laid-back city builder that never takes itself too seriously. Perfect if you want strategy without stress and a good laugh along the way.

This is my first entry to both Tropico and city building games, and I absolutely love it! A nice mix between city building, industry management and, the thing that apparently sets Tropico apart from all its competitors, politics. Trying to keep all the different factions within and outside your borders happy makes sure you'll never run out of things to do and the factions also affect how you run your republic. The game isn't difficult to learn at all. The in-game tutorial does a very good job explaining all the basics and I had no problem jumping into sandbox mode. Of course the tutorial can't explain absolutely everything, but luckily the game is 6 years old, so all your basic questions have been asked before and can be easily found with a quick Google search. 

The game is ridiculously addicting, though! One Saturday I made myself some morning coffee and, having finished the tutorial the night before, I decided to try the sandbox mode. I am not exaggerating at all when I say that I did not take even a quick bathroom break for the next 5,5 hours. I had to practically force myself to quit the game and get something to eat. The next day I decided to play the game again with my morning coffee and promised to only play 2 hours max so the entire day isn't wasted. Four hours later I once again found myself having to literally force myself to quit the game. I can't remember the last time this happaned. Maybe in early 2010s with Skyrim or late 2000s with WoW. There's just something unbelievably addicting about the gameplay loop.

The game doesn't have a proper campaign but isolated missions instead. They're basically the same as the sandbox but with extra goals, challenges and features (like in first mission, where you send coconuts to your gold mines to create gold-filled coconuts, which you can tell sell to smugglers to fund your independence). I've only played the first one but I'll definitely be trying the rest too.

negative.review:
A lot to like, a lot more buildings and complexity, but the late game management in modern era just falls apart over time. Guerilla fighters become more and more prelevant (even at 100% approval) to the point where it's literal swarms at all times, and for whatever reason your military guys don't live at their military base so they have to drive over every single time, which lets the fighters move in and light 8 buildings on fire before your military even 'spawns' 

Ultimatums from super powers can flat end your game. Especially if a superpower decides to just simply issue 2 at once, you auto game over. No chance to fight them off on the 'invasion' you just lose automatically. Disease sucks and makes the game unplayable. For all the good it has with building beauty and graphics and more buildings in general, 6 fails to play as well as 4 or 5.

[h1]One small nitpick[/h1]

[b][u][i]Please[/i][/u][/b] add a bind to arrest the selected citizen. My wrist hurts from arresting over >40 criminals, because in colonial era arresting is a manual task, which if not done can cost over $3000 a month.

Disappointing. I played Tropico 3 and liked it very much, especially the satirical humour based on playing a ruthless dictator who skillfully pulls money from the great world powers' pockets while basically oppressing their own people and using military force if the osterity measures went a bit too far.
Here, this feeling is gone. It feels more like a regular city building simulator.
- There are demands that you have to meet or you will not be reelected / your citizens riot. You feel much more like their servant than their ruler.
- There are several interest groups with significant power. If you do not fulfil their demands, they can impose significant penalties. You can't weaken their influence or get rid of them, even if their presence on your island simply makes no sense. There will always be environmentalists, capitalists or democracy advocates. Even the relationship to the world powers feels more like groweling before their feet and accepting close monitoring and supervision instead of playing them like a fiddle.
- Additionally, there are some strange things with the economy which I needed to figure out. In a playthrough that gave me several gold deposits, I was constantly broke. The numbers just didn't match, even after establishing factories to produce jewellery from that gold. Mostly, it was the agriculture that kept me afloat. It felt strange.

Lots of things to be desired in this game (like a return to Tropico 5 paid dollar amounts rather than "class categories") but other things are interesting (such as spread islands, bridge, and tunnel buildings). The only reason I mark is as Not Recommended is because you *need* some of the DLC to make it more sensible to play (why spread the islands and then give very little stuff to build on all this open water? Oh to sell DLC that gives you that stuff to build)

Game plays fine until everybody has cars. Sounds great, doesn't work.  Traffic jams just happen out of nowhere when one citizen decides they aren't going to drive ever again until they starve in their car on the road. It grinds your entire economy to a halt. Teamsters, firefighters, and workers in general just quietly stop working, nothing gets to your docks for export, and your very profitable set-up goes to (schist). Game does not rock.

I just can't find myself enjoying this game. I try, but it just isn't that much fun. I love the new infrastructure and I am glad they got rid of the Dynasty aspect of the 5th game, but it just takes most of what I didn't like about the 5th game and expands on it, making a lot of things that should be simple either very complicated or time consuming. 
The missions also aren't exactly great. Not terrible by any means, but their piecemeal nature detaches you from it and instead of a coherent narrative, you get what can barely be called an "episodic" experience. 

To put it bluntly, if you think Tropico 4 is better than Tropico 5, then this game will be a big disappointment to you. 
If you instead prefer all the changes brought with the 5th installment, then you will probably like this. 

It is no way near as smooth or funny to play as the 4th game and I do not think the added complexity, real and forced simply because the gameplay mechanics have been worsened, is a welcome addition to the game.

Initially, I was happy to find Tropico 6 way more challenging than the previous entries (I'm a Tropico fan, but tbh these games are just too easy).

In a several hours long session, I decided to save, exit and relaunch my save as performances were seriously tanking for some reason (went under 55FPS, and came back to +125FPS after reloading; I guess it's because of Unreal Engine).

Then after reloading, I realized the game wasn't harder at all, but just buggier. All the stats I was laboriously trying to up were badly calculated (happiness, approval and so on).

I will keep playing it because I like the gameplay and wanna finish the campaign, but I can't recommend it. At least I've not (yet) encountered any game breaking bugs, like in Tropico 5.

On standard difficulty the economy is extremely tight.  Most crops barely pull in enough money to paying your farmers.  Manufactured goods are better - but come with additional costs.  Also the happiness gauge seems ridiculously low.  With factions and personal happiness running 40% to 70% my personal rating was  23%.  A game that should have been about choices in building for long times involved waiting for my economy to strengthen so I could do anything.  I've finished both Tropico 4 and Tropico 5 so stow that "Git gud".  In earlier games a couple of industries with the right edicts could ensure your prosperity, here I can have eight to ten upgraded industries and still be struggling to make ends meet.  A lot of options  and upgrades have more negatives than they are worth.

Access to buildings is covered by wealth so the poor have no way to have their happiness reach the higher levels.

 There are irritants.  Crop harvesting doesn't feel real, and nor does any other production building.    I couldn't see Tropicans developing skills.  It takes ages to open up edicts that you'd never voluntarily pass.  One scenario required you to choose certain options for a newspaper without ever having a way to unlock them.

  Tropicos 4 and 5 are significantly better than this one and there's too little in what's new here that increases the fun.

I've played a lot of the Tropico series, but I really struggled with this one. The distance citizens needs to travel is key to an effective economy, workers will happily commute across the entire map wasting much time, but there seems to be little you can do to stop this. The game doesn't alert you to this issue, nor does it offer any kind of useful information to help you pinpoint the issue.

I do not understand the economy and hidden logistics of this game. My treasury always goes into minus and then never bounces back, no matter what I do and how careful I am. Some trade routes are stuck in 0 despite all other aspects being in place. People will remain broke even with plenty of jobs and home happinness never goes above 40% even when there is plenty of housing and free housing edict. I do get it's a complex game but come on, it's just not fun when you fail 5 times for the same reasons!

Disappointing. I played Tropico 3 and liked it very much, especially the satirical humour based on playing a ruthless dictator who skillfully pulls money from the great world powers' pockets while basically oppressing their own people and using military force if the osterity measures went a bit too far.
Here, this feeling is gone. It feels more like a regular city building simulator.
- There are demands that you have to meet or you will not be reelected / your citizens riot. You feel much more like their servant than their ruler.
- There are several interest groups with significant power. If you do not fulfil their demands, they can impose significant penalties. You can't weaken their influence or get rid of them, even if their presence on your island simply makes no sense. There will always be environmentalists, capitalists or democracy advocates. Even the relationship to the world powers feels more like groweling before their feet and accepting close monitoring and supervision instead of playing them like a fiddle.
- Additionally, there are some strange things with the economy which I needed to figure out. In a playthrough that gave me several gold deposits, I was constantly broke. The numbers just didn't match, even after establishing factories to produce jewellery from that gold. Mostly, it was the agriculture that kept me afloat. It felt strange.

To me, the specificity of the missions takes the fun out of the Tropico concept. I'm unable to even finish several of the first maps because I run into either an irrecoverable deficit in spite of putting up plantations etc. in order to export, or I lose the election for reasons I don't understand. Having to select specific trade deals annoys me, and those Pirate Cove missions are basically random and silly, and the limitation to certain historic periods constrains the possibilities too much. Several of the scenarios start with a given set of superfluous, costly buildings, or in a weird geographical setting, which seems to be intended to contribute to the difficulty of winning, which I find arbitrary and frustrating. I like to build and expand, and for a game to allow some freedom in how to win, but this game to me seems to allow only for certain, fairly narrow paths of success that I'm unable to find. Sorry for not being able to be more specific. I'm quite certain that lack of intelligence on my part isn't the problem here. I loved Tropico 3, 4 and 5. But somehow Tropico 6 - which I've tried repeatedly over the years - just doesn't do it for me. Can't recommend.

Lots of things to be desired in this game (like a return to Tropico 5 paid dollar amounts rather than "class categories") but other things are interesting (such as spread islands, bridge, and tunnel buildings). The only reason I mark is as Not Recommended is because you *need* some of the DLC to make it more sensible to play (why spread the islands and then give very little stuff to build on all this open water? Oh to sell DLC that gives you that stuff to build)

Game plays fine until everybody has cars. Sounds great, doesn't work.  Traffic jams just happen out of nowhere when one citizen decides they aren't going to drive ever again until they starve in their car on the road. It grinds your entire economy to a halt. Teamsters, firefighters, and workers in general just quietly stop working, nothing gets to your docks for export, and your very profitable set-up goes to (schist). Game does not rock.

I just can't find myself enjoying this game. I try, but it just isn't that much fun. I love the new infrastructure and I am glad they got rid of the Dynasty aspect of the 5th game, but it just takes most of what I didn't like about the 5th game and expands on it, making a lot of things that should be simple either very complicated or time consuming. 
The missions also aren't exactly great. Not terrible by any means, but their piecemeal nature detaches you from it and instead of a coherent narrative, you get what can barely be called an "episodic" experience. 

To put it bluntly, if you think Tropico 4 is better than Tropico 5, then this game will be a big disappointment to you. 
If you instead prefer all the changes brought with the 5th installment, then you will probably like this. 

It is no way near as smooth or funny to play as the 4th game and I do not think the added complexity, real and forced simply because the gameplay mechanics have been worsened, is a welcome addition to the game.

Initially, I was happy to find Tropico 6 way more challenging than the previous entries (I'm a Tropico fan, but tbh these games are just too easy).

In a several hours long session, I decided to save, exit and relaunch my save as performances were seriously tanking for some reason (went under 55FPS, and came back to +125FPS after reloading; I guess it's because of Unreal Engine).

Then after reloading, I realized the game wasn't harder at all, but just buggier. All the stats I was laboriously trying to up were badly calculated (happiness, approval and so on).

I will keep playing it because I like the gameplay and wanna finish the campaign, but I can't recommend it. At least I've not (yet) encountered any game breaking bugs, like in Tropico 5.
Out of the last 3, I can only really recommend Tropico 4.

No recommendation.

On standard difficulty the economy is extremely tight.  Most crops barely pull in enough money to paying your farmers.  Manufactured goods are better - but come with additional costs.  Also the happiness gauge seems ridiculously low.  With factions and personal happiness running 40% to 70% my personal rating was  23%.  A game that should have been about choices in building for long times involved waiting for my economy to strengthen so I could do anything.  I've finished both Tropico 4 and Tropico 5 so stow that "Git gud".  In earlier games a couple of industries with the right edicts could ensure your prosperity, here I can have eight to ten upgraded industries and still be struggling to make ends meet.  A lot of options  and upgrades have more negatives than they are worth.

Access to buildings is covered by wealth so the poor have no way to have their happiness reach the higher levels.

 There are irritants.  Crop harvesting doesn't feel real, and nor does any other production building.    I couldn't see Tropicans developing skills.  It takes ages to open up edicts that you'd never voluntarily pass.  One scenario required you to choose certain options for a newspaper without ever having a way to unlock them.

  Tropicos 4 and 5 are significantly better than this one and there's too little in what's new here that increases the fun.

S.x.

I loved tropico 4 and 5. They were different, but you could still have fun with both. Here it seems they forgot to add the fun. Being constanly attacked by pirates is so fun, none of the starting buildings being profitable is also so fun. Hard pass.

A lot to like, a lot more buildings and complexity, but the late game management in modern era just falls apart over time. Guerilla fighters become more and more prelevant (even at 100% approval) to the point where it's literal swarms at all times, and for whatever reason your military guys don't live at their military base so they have to drive over every single time, which lets the fighters move in and light 8 buildings on fire before your military even 'spawns' 

Ultimatums from super powers can flat end your game. Especially if a superpower decides to just simply issue 2 at once, you auto game over. No chance to fight them off on the 'invasion' you just lose automatically. Disease sucks and makes the game unplayable. For all the good it has with building beauty and graphics and more buildings in general, 6 fails to play as well as 4 or 5.

I played Tropico 3 and liked it very much, especially the satirical humour based on playing a ruthless dictator who skillfully pulls money from the great world powers' pockets while basically oppressing their own people and using military force if the osterity measures went a bit too far.
Here, this feeling is gone. It feels more like a regular city building simulator.
- There are demands that you have to meet or you will not be reelected / your citizens riot. You feel much more like their servant than their ruler.
- There are several interest groups with significant power. If you do not fulfil their demands, they can impose significant penalties. You can't weaken their influence or get rid of them, even if their presence on your island simply makes no sense. There will always be environmentalists, capitalists or democracy advocates. Even the relationship to the world powers feels more like groweling before their feet and accepting close monitoring and supervision instead of playing them like a fiddle.
- Additionally, there are some strange things with the economy which I needed to figure out. In a playthrough that gave me several gold deposits, I was constantly broke. The numbers just didn't match, even after establishing factories to produce jewellery from that gold. Mostly, it was the agriculture that kept me afloat. It felt strange.

To me, the specificity of the missions takes the fun out of the Tropico concept. I'm unable to even finish several of the first maps because I run into either an irrecoverable deficit in spite of putting up plantations etc. in order to export, or I lose the election for reasons I don't understand. Having to select specific trade deals annoys me, and those Pirate Cove missions are basically random and silly, and the limitation to certain historic periods constrains the possibilities too much. Several of the scenarios start with a given set of superfluous, costly buildings, or in a weird geographical setting, which seems to be intended to contribute to the difficulty of winning, which I find arbitrary and frustrating. I like to build and expand, and for a game to allow some freedom in how to win, but this game to me seems to allow only for certain, fairly narrow paths of success that I'm unable to find. Sorry for not being able to be more specific. I'm quite certain that lack of intelligence on my part isn't the problem here. I loved Tropico 3, 4 and 5. But somehow Tropico 6 - which I've tried repeatedly over the years - just doesn't do it for me. Can't recommend.

Lots of things to be desired in this game (like a return to Tropico 5 paid dollar amounts rather than "class categories") but other things are interesting (such as spread islands, bridge, and tunnel buildings). The only reason I mark is as Not Recommended is because you *need* some of the DLC to make it more sensible to play (why spread the islands and then give very little stuff to build on all this open water? Oh to sell DLC that gives you that stuff to build)

Game plays fine until everybody has cars. Sounds great, doesn't work.  Traffic jams just happen out of nowhere when one citizen decides they aren't going to drive ever again until they starve in their car on the road. It grinds your entire economy to a halt. Teamsters, firefighters, and workers in general just quietly stop working, nothing gets to your docks for export, and your very profitable set-up goes to (schist). Game does not rock.

I just can't find myself enjoying this game. I try, but it just isn't that much fun. I love the new infrastructure and I am glad they got rid of the Dynasty aspect of the 5th game, but it just takes most of what I didn't like about the 5th game and expands on it, making a lot of things that should be simple either very complicated or time consuming. 
The missions also aren't exactly great. Not terrible by any means, but their piecemeal nature detaches you from it and instead of a coherent narrative, you get what can barely be called an "episodic" experience. 

To put it bluntly, if you think Tropico 4 is better than Tropico 5, then this game will be a big disappointment to you. 
If you instead prefer all the changes brought with the 5th installment, then you will probably like this. 

It is no way near as smooth or funny to play as the 4th game and I do not think the added complexity, real and forced simply because the gameplay mechanics have been worsened, is a welcome addition to the game.

Initially, I was happy to find Tropico 6 way more challenging than the previous entries (I'm a Tropico fan, but tbh these games are just too easy).

In a several hours long session, I decided to save, exit and relaunch my save as performances were seriously tanking for some reason (went under 55FPS, and came back to +125FPS after reloading; I guess it's because of Unreal Engine).

Then after reloading, I realized the game wasn't harder at all, but just buggier. All the stats I was laboriously trying to up were badly calculated (happiness, approval and so on).

I will keep playing it because I like the gameplay and wanna finish the campaign, but I can't recommend it. At least I've not (yet) encountered any game breaking bugs, like in Tropico 5.
Out of the last 3, I can only really recommend Tropico 4.

No recommendation.

On standard difficulty the economy is extremely tight.  Most crops barely pull in enough money to paying your farmers.  Manufactured goods are better - but come with additional costs.  Also the happiness gauge seems ridiculously low.  With factions and personal happiness running 40% to 70% my personal rating was  23%.  A game that should have been about choices in building for long times involved waiting for my economy to strengthen so I could do anything.  I've finished both Tropico 4 and Tropico 5 so stow that "Git gud".  In earlier games a couple of industries with the right edicts could ensure your prosperity, here I can have eight to ten upgraded industries and still be struggling to make ends meet.  A lot of options  and upgrades have more negatives than they are worth.

Access to buildings is covered by wealth so the poor have no way to have their happiness reach the higher levels.

 There are irritants.  Crop harvesting doesn't feel real, and nor does any other production building.    I couldn't see Tropicans developing skills.  It takes ages to open up edicts that you'd never voluntarily pass.  One scenario required you to choose certain options for a newspaper without ever having a way to unlock them.

  Tropicos 4 and 5 are significantly better than this one and there's too little in what's new here that increases the fun.

S.x.

I loved tropico 4 and 5. They were different, but you could still have fun with both. Here it seems they forgot to add the fun. Being constanly attacked by pirates is so fun, none of the starting buildings being profitable is also so fun. Hard pass.

A lot to like, a lot more buildings and complexity, but the late game management in modern era just falls apart over time. Guerilla fighters become more and more prelevant (even at 100% approval) to the point where it's literal swarms at all times, and for whatever reason your military guys don't live at their military base so they have to drive over every single time, which lets the fighters move in and light 8 buildings on fire before your military even 'spawns' 

Ultimatums from super powers can flat end your game. Especially if a superpower decides to just simply issue 2 at once, you auto game over. No chance to fight them off on the 'invasion' you just lose automatically. Disease sucks and makes the game unplayable. For all the good it has with building beauty and graphics and more buildings in general, 6 fails to play as well as 4 or 5.

[h1]One small nitpick[/h1]

[b][u][i]Please[/i][/u][/b] add a bind to arrest the selected citizen. My wrist hurts from arresting over >40 criminals, because in colonial era arresting is a manual task, which if not done can cost over $3000 a month.

Its not as good as 4. Its also buggier than 4 and is a lot more difficult than 4.
The map size is too small honestly and when you change to different time periods your economy always collapses the game doesn't give you enough time to prepare for the shift you have to pre-emptively prepare for it by not taking the quest - tropico 5 has a similar problem. This one just isn't as fun to play as the others.
Game has crashed 4 times since I started playing it, in less than 2 hours. Couldn't even make it through the tutorial.

I get that the humour is the selling point for Tropico now, but I liked it better when it was just sprinkled on top rather than injected throughout. I'll probably still play it, it's still fills a unique niche in the city-building genre, but I wouldn't dedicate several weekends just to build the city of my dreams like I might do with a Sim City, Anno or Caesar game.

I like the few new building in the a game as well as the multi island concept. Personally I enjoyed Tropica 5 in more ways then this newer rendition. This game has a weird learning curve as well as more pressure on politics compared to the fun and easy game play of 5. Honestly I play five more then this game and not get as frustrated with the campaigns which is odd.

This game is going in the wrong direction.  This version I just can't bring myself to play.  The islands aren't fun, the missions are preset, and there isn't anything new.  I prefer to play missions my own way.

I've played a lot of the Tropico series, but I really struggled with this one. The distance citizens needs to travel is key to an effective economy, workers will happily commute across the entire map wasting much time, but there seems to be little you can do to stop this. The game doesn't alert you to this issue, nor does it offer any kind of useful information to help you pinpoint the issue.

I do not understand the economy and hidden logistics of this game. My treasury always goes into minus and then never bounces back, no matter what I do and how careful I am. Some trade routes are stuck in 0 despite all other aspects being in place. People will remain broke even with plenty of jobs and home happinness never goes above 40% even when there is plenty of housing and free housing edict. I do get it's a complex game but come on, it's just not fun when you fail 5 times for the same reasons!
